Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this proposal is to measure and model the native interfacial adhesion between polymers or metal coated polymers and bio-tissues using a contact mechanics approach. Bio-integrated electronics are a class of ultra-thin, ultra-soft, stretchable electronics which can conformably integrate with the soft, curvilinear and kinetic surfaces of bio-tissues for sensing, treatment, and communication. Conformable and robust binding between bio-tissues and electronics components can be obtained directly by such intrinsic adhesive interactions without recourse to intermediate adhesives or conductive gels. The proposed research will initiate a contact mechanics approach pertinent to bio-tissues through a combination of experiments and analytical/numerical modeling. We propose to develop a custom tissue tack tester capable of displacement control, measurement of contact load, and in situ monitoring of the contact area. Experimental data will be used in conjunction with contact mechanics models to determine the work of adhesion and traction-separation relations as the continuum representation of the adhesive interactions between various biotic-abiotic contact pairs. The effects of rate-dependence, tissue roughness, and bio-fluids will be considered.

Native adhesive interactions between electronic materials and bio-tissues as characterized by this research will be the key parameter in predicting interface reliability and in guiding the rational design of the mechanical structure of bio-integrated circuits. Outcomes from the proposed research will be assimilated into a new graduate level, school-wide, multidisciplinary course. Texas demographics are such that the undergraduate body at UT-Austin has a significant Hispanic representation (~17% in the Cockrell School of Engineering), who we have successfully encouraged to participate in our undergraduate outreach programs. The PI is a committee member of the UT Austin Women in Engineering Programs (WEP) and has dedicated herself as a mentor for underrepresented undergraduate and K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this award, we have measured and modeled the native interfacial adhesions between different soft polymers as well as between stretchable electronics and bio-tissues. To measure the adhesion between soft polymers, we applied the Johnson-Kendall-Roberts (JKR) method with proper corrections for ultra-soft materials. The work of adhesion/separation between soft elastomers of wide cross-linking ratios are summarized in Fig. 1 [1]. Polymer-tissue adhesion has also been measured through pull-off tests [2]. Knowing the interfacial adhesion, we have developed an analytical solution to predict device-tissue conformability as shown in Fig. 2 [3], which is critical for the performance of bio-electronics. We have also built fracture mechanics models to explain and guide in vivo cell sheet transfer for wound healing [4]. To create a removable tissue adhesive that are strong during attachment but easy to remove and reuse, we have engineered micro-surface craters as shown in Fig. 3 [2]. The mechanics of surface craters has been thoroughly studied through experimental and modeling means and a design map has been created to guide the design of the cratered dry adhesives [5].

We developed a framework for extracting traction-separation relations (TSR), which combines the field projection method and an iterative method to solve Cauchy problems. Two loading devices were built to separately characterize the TSR between polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and polystyrene. A double cantilever beam with electromechanical sensors generated minimal data of load, displacement, beam end rotation and crack length as input data to extract the interfacial response (Fig. 4) [6]. In another setup, geometric shadow moiré [7] was used to measure, full field, out of plane deformation of the top adherend of a double cantilever beam (Fig. 5) [8] and this information was the input data used to determine interfacial response. Results obtained from tests performed at different loading rates highlighted that the interfacial behavior between the elastomer (PDMS) adhesive and polystyrene adherend exhibit rate dependent delamination behavior (Fig. 6). In addition, the results obtained from the two approaches were very consistent.

 

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this research project derives from the complexity associated with the contact of bio-tissues through viscoelastic effects, surface topology, as well as the presence of bio-fluid at the interface. We have established a theoretical-experimental framework for the quantification and analysis of native adhesive interactions between soft polymers and bio-tissues. The knowledge has been applied to guide the fabrication of bio-electronics and the transfer of cell sheets. The reusable cratered adhesives we invented for bio-electronics is a transformative surface structure for many other applications such as vertical mounting and wall climbing. Traction separation relations are fundamentally important to describe the constitutive response of both adhesive and cohesive interfaces. Departing from the heuristic nature of existing methods, the intellectual merit of this work derives from developing a framework to independently solve for the tractions and displacements by redefining the problem at hand as a Cauchy inverse boundary value problem.

Broader Impacts: Native adhesive interactions between electronic materials and bio-tissues as characterized by this research will be the key parameter in predicting interface reliability and in guiding the rationalized design of the mechanical structure of soft bio-electronics. Soft bio-electronics create new opportunities for studying disease states, improving surgical procedures, monitoring health/wellness, establishing human-machine interfaces and many others. Two PhD students, one Masters student, and three minority undergraduate students were supported by this project. They have published journal articles and presented their work in international conferences. Outcomes from this research has been assimilated into the PI’s graduate course “Thin Film Mechanics”, which is an interdisciplinary course cross-listed between the ASE/EM and BME departments. Starting 2014, the PI’s lab open house on the Explore UT day would host more than 200 K-12 students each year.

 

1.           Yu, Y.L., D. Sanchez, and N. Lu, Work of adhesion/separation between soft elastomers of different mixing ratios. Journal of Materials Research, 2015. 30(18): p. 2702-2712.

2.           Choi, M.K., et. al., Cephalopod-Inspired Miniaturized Suction Cups for Smart Medical Skin. Advanced Healthcare Materials, 2015. 5(1): p. 80-87.

3.           Wang, L. and N. Lu, Conformability of a Thin Elastic Membrane Laminated on a Soft Substrate With Slightly Wavy Surface. Journal of Applied Mechanics, 2016. 83(4): p. 041007.

4.           Kim, S.J., et al., Multifunctional Cell-Culture Platform for Aligned Cell Sheet Monitoring, Transfer Printing, and Therapy. Acs Nano, 2015. 9(3): p. 2677-2688.

5.           Qiao, S., L. Wang, K.M. Liechti, G. Rodin, and N. Lu, Pull-off forces of cratered polymers, 2017. In preparation.

6.           Palvadi, N.S., N. Lu, and K.M. Liechti, Extracting traction-separation relations from minimal data, 2017. In preparation.

7.           Palvadi, N.S. and K.M. Liechti, Improving the resolution of shadow moire, 2017. In preparation.

8.           Palvadi, N.S., N. Lu, and K.M. Liechti, Extracting traction separation relations from full displacement data, 2017. In preparation.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In this award, we have measured and modeled the native interfacial adhesions between different soft polymers as well as between stretchable electronics and bio-tissues. To measure the adhesion between soft polymers, we applied the Johnson-Kendall-Roberts (JKR) method with proper corrections for ultra-soft materials. The work of adhesion/separation between soft elastomers of wide cross-linking ratios are summarized in Fig. 1 [1]. Polymer-tissue adhesion has also been measured through pull-off tests [2]. Knowing the interfacial adhesion, we have developed an analytical solution to predict device-tissue conformability as shown in Fig. 2 [3], which is critical for the performance of bio-electronics. We have also built fracture mechanics models to explain and guide in vivo cell sheet transfer for wound healing [4]. To create a removable tissue adhesive that are strong during attachment but easy to remove and reuse, we have engineered micro-surface craters as shown in Fig. 3 [2]. The mechanics of surface craters has been thoroughly studied through experimental and modeling means and a design map has been created to guide the design of the cratered dry adhesives [5]. We developed a framework for extracting traction-separation relations (TSR), which combines the field projection method and an iterative method to solve Cauchy problems. Two loading devices were built to separately characterize the TSR between polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and polystyrene. A double cantilever beam with electromechanical sensors generated minimal data of load, displacement, beam end rotation and crack length as input data to extract the interfacial response (Fig. 4) [6]. In another setup, geometric shadow moiré [7] was used to measure, full field, out of plane deformation of the top adherend of a double cantilever beam (Fig. 5) [8] and this information was the input data used to determine interfacial response. Results obtained from tests performed at different loading rates highlighted that the interfacial behavior between the elastomer (PDMS) adhesive and polystyrene adherend exhibit rate dependent delamination behavior (Fig. 6). In addition, the results obtained from the two approaches were very consistent. We have established a theoretical-experimental framework for the quantification and analysis of native adhesive interactions between soft polymers and bio-tissues. The knowledge has been applied to guide the fabrication of bio-electronics and the transfer of cell sheets. The reusable cratered adhesives we invented for bio-electronics is a transformative surface structure for many other applications such as vertical mounting and wall climbing. Traction separation relations are fundamentally important to describe the constitutive response of both adhesive and cohesive interfaces. Departing from the heuristic nature of existing methods, the intellectual merit of this work derives from developing a framework to independently solve for the tractions and displacements by redefining the problem at hand as a Cauchy inverse boundary value problem. Soft bio-electronics create new opportunities for studying disease states, improving surgical procedures, monitoring health/wellness, establishing human-machine interfaces and many others. Two PhD students, one Masters student, and three minority undergraduate students were supported by this project. They have published journal articles and presented their work in international conferences.
